p: Furthermore, a study conducted by Rasool et al. looked at the activity of aqueous extracts of ginger and garlic on anti-avian influenza virus H 9N 2, in chick embryos. Results obtained showed that the aqueous extract of ginger exhibited antiviral activity at 10, 15, 20 and 25%, whereas in the case of garlic, antiviral activity was observed at 15, 20 and 25%. Moreover, MTT assays revealed that both plants displayed cytotoxicity, which was in a dose-dependent manner; however, extracts of ginger exhibited lower cytotoxicity in comparison to ginger. From this study, it can be concluded that aqueous extract of ginger showed great antiviral activity against H 9N 2 and was less cytotoxic to cells with a cell survival rate of more than 50% [ 45]. Thus, it can be assumed that ginger may have the potential to become a promising natural antiviral agent; however, in order for this to happen, further investigation is still required.
